questions.text: What does George's girlfriend order at the restaurant in the beginning of the episode?
questions.explanation:
Lobster.

	During the dinner, George's girlfriend breaks out crying because she can't be with George anymore.  She says that her parents wouldn't approve of the relationship because of their religion, so she has to end it.  After this, the waiter comes over and she orders a twenty-five dollar lobster.

questions.text: What religion does George try to get involved with?
questions.explanation:
Latvian Orthodox.

	On the night after the dinner, George speaks with Jerry and Elaine about his Latvian Orthodox girlfriend and his disappointment in knowing that they can't be together.  Elaine says that it would be romantic to convert to Latvian Orthodox for her as a joke and George decides to go through with it.

questions.text: Where does Jerry find the fungicide?
questions.explanation:
In a medicine cabinet.

	While washing his hands in his girlfriend's apartment, Jerry nudges her medicine cabinet open a little and happens to notice fungicide on the top shelf.  The next day, Jerry mentions this to Elaine and Kramer at the coffee shop and Elaine accuses Jerry of snooping.  Kramer sides with Jerry and says that he always opens cabinets.

questions.text: When asked about what he likes about the religion, what does George say?
options: He is interested on the whole
questions.explanation:
He likes the hats.

	George goes to the Latvian Orthodox church and the priests ask him many questions.  In the end, they find that he is sincere about joining and they give him some thick books to read about their religion.  After this, Sister Roberta is introduced.

questions.text: What does Sister Roberta give to Kramer as a gift?
questions.explanation:
A Slinky.

	Kramer thinks that Sister Roberta is starting to like Kramer although Jerry thinks that he's a bit crazy.  Meanwhile, Jerry's girlfriend comes by and Jerry continues to pretend to be sick.  George suggests looking at the fungicide again to see if it was actually hers, so he asks to use her bathroom and checks.

Podiatrist.

	Throughout the episode, many of the characters refer to him as a podiatrist because they don't see him as a real doctor.  On one date, Elaine is about to ask him about the fungicide, but they get into a long argument about how podiatrists aren't doctors.

questions.text: Where does George study the religious books for his conversion?
questions.explanation:
In a bathroom.

	In order to prevent his parents from discovering that he's converting to Latvian Orthodox just to date his girlfriend, George hides away in the bathroom.  When he's in there for more than an hour, his parents start yelling at him and his mother thinks that something is wrong.

questions.text: Did George pass his conversion test?
questions.explanation:
Yes.

	Although George was nervous about the test and although he nearly cheated by writing the answers on his hand, George pulled through and the priests were impressed with George's work.  Meanwhile, Kramer talks with the priest about Sister Roberta.  The priest says that Kramer has the power of 'kevorka', which in Latvian means 'the lure of the animal'.

questions.text: Do George's parents find out about the conversion?
questions.explanation:
Yes.

	When George's name appears on the church bulletin board, friends of George's parents release the news and they find out.  They beg George not to change religions and Frank threatens to call his lawyer.  Frank also thinks that George is joining a religion that mutilates squirrels although George denies this.

questions.text: What is the name of Jerry's girlfriend's cat?
questions.explanation:
Bonkers.

	In the end, Jerry discovers that the fungicide was for his girlfriend's cat, and when Kramer gets rid of his power, he runs to the conversion to stop Sister Roberta from losing her faith.  Meanwhile, Elaine's podiatrist breaks up with her when he finds the cat's fungicide in Elaine's medicine cabinet.  George doesn't get to stay with his girlfriend because she's going to Latvia for a year.
